title: Samobor
text:
Samobor () is a town in <a href="Zagreb%20County">Zagreb County</a>, <a href="Croatia">Croatia</a>. It has a population of 15,956 inhabitants in the <a href="City%20proper">town proper</a>, with 37,633 in the administrative area. It is part of the <a href="Zagreb">Zagreb</a> <a href="metropolitan%20area">metropolitan area</a>.
Geography.
Samobor is located west of <a href="Zagreb">Zagreb</a>, between the eastern slopes of the Samobor hills (), the eastern part of <a href="%C5%BDumberak%20Mountains">Žumberak Mountains</a>, in the <a href="Sava">Sava River</a> valley. It is part of the historical region of <a href="Croatia%20proper">Croatia proper</a>.
History.
Samobor has existed as a <a href="free%20royal%20town">free royal town</a> since 1242, according to a document of endowment by King <a href="B%C3%A9la%20IV">Béla IV</a>.
Since the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Karlowitz">Treaty of Karlowitz</a> in 1699, "Szamobor" was part of the <a href="Habsburg%20Monarchy">Habsburg Monarchy</a>, (<a href="Transleithania">Transleithania</a> after the <a href="compromise%20of%201867">compromise of 1867</a>), and soon after in the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Croatia-Slavonia">Kingdom of Croatia-Slavonia</a>, created when the Kingdom of Slavonia and the Kingdom of Croatia were merged in 1868. In the late 19th and early 20th century, Samobor was a district capital in the <a href="Zagreb%20County%20%28former%29">Zagreb County</a> of the Kingdom of Croatia-Slavonia.
Economy.
One of the chief industries in Samobor is <a href="lead%20crystal">crystal</a> cutting, acclaimed in Europe and all over the world.

Monuments and sightseeings.
Samobor is one of the earliest tourist resorts in the region, with the first tourist facilities dating back to 1810, catering to <a href="Angling">anglers</a>, <a href="hunter">hunter</a>s and <a href="hiker">hiker</a>s. The town's beautiful surroundings and vicinity to the capital have supported this tourist tradition to the present day. In 1846, Samobor was paid a visit by the composer <a href="Franz%20Liszt">Franz Liszt</a>, who at that time was visiting Zagreb during one of his numerous concert tours. Liszt came to Samobor to see his friend Ferdo Livadić, in his lodgings at the <a href="http%3A//www.bravo-la.com/images/Samoborpostcrd2.JPG">Livadić mansion</a>, which is today the town museum.
At the beginning of the 20th century, the Livadić mansion came under the ownership of a Jewish family named Daničić. They were forced to leave as a result of the Nazi invasion in 1941. Shortly after this, the mansion was
confiscated by the newly formed Independent State of Croatia and never returned to the Daničić family.

Sport.
The local football club is <a href="NK%20Samobor">NK Samobor</a>, who play in the <a href="Tre%C4%87a%20HNL">Treća HNL</a>.
The local woman's handball club is <a href="%C5%BDRK%20Samobor">ŽRK Samobor</a>, who play in the Prva HRL.
The local men's handball clubs are <a href="RK%20MladosT%2009">RK MladosT 09</a>, and <a href="RK%20Rudar">RK Rudar</a>, who play in the <a href="Premijer%20liga">Premijer liga</a>.
The local basketball club is <a href="KK%20Samobor">KK Samobor</a>, who play in the <a href="Druga%20mu%C5%A1ka%20liga%2C%20reija%20Centar">Druga muška liga, reija Centar</a>.
The local judo club is <a href="Judo%20Klub%20Samobor">Judo Klub Samobor</a>.
The local karate club is <a href="Karate%20klub%20Samobor">Karate klub Samobor</a>.
